comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: That is a wide street. From the spacing of the tram tracks, I think it has to be Upper O'Connell Street.. Across most of the tram network, the tracks in both directions are side-by-side, not widely separated like this.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
From the account in the London Times the following day:
On the six mile route of the long procession not a single barrier was to be seen nor a rank of soldiers or policemen engaged in keeping the crowds back. Yet the sidewalks were lined three to five deep on either hand the whole way. For sheer impressiveness the presence of such long extending walls of citizens - just the common people, mostly in everyday clothes - outdid even the funeral procession.

comment._content: What a great photo! The photographer found a great vantage point.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: History records that Michael Collins died at Bealnablath. Modern writers have decided that the proper name is Beal-na-mBlath which means the "mouth of the Flowers" How appropriate! From - generalmichaelcollins.com/Michael_Collins_Life_and_Times/...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Nice photos here from St Vincents Hospital, City Hall, pro Cathedral and Glasnevin. multitext.ucc.ie/viewgallery/1308 Some of our flowers can be seen in the last few photographs.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: "Brains of lead and eyes of glass as the cortege, three miles long, moved swiftly with its army of wreath-laden, crepe-draped lorries, its seventeen bands moaning Handel’s Funeral March, its Archbishops and Bishops in solemn canonical robes, its advance guard of cavalry, its Generals, Captains and grey-green firing party, fifty strong, with rifles reversed, and buglers in the rear, its mourners afoot and in coaches, file after file of working men, clerks, students, clergymen, women, officials, all passing swiftly in the wake of the coffin on an eighteen-pounder gun-carriage drawn by six stable horses. The sun pouring down on six miles of spectators as the procession flashed by with mournful pride to Glasnevin, where O’Connell’s lime-white Round Tower soared sentinel to the newest corner and comrade in the Irish Pantheon. Mourners afoot, mourners lining the streets, mourners on the roofs, with the sun pouring down and the silence of doom over all as the Funeral March stops and Dublin follows, looks on in wondering heartache and stupefied anger, sobs quietly and pays a last homage to Michael Collins in his coffin drawn by six stable horses to an eternal sleep in the heart of his nation, dark hair quiescent now, vibrating accent stilled and determined jaw set forever" (Desmond Ryan). From - sarasmichaelcollinssite.com/collins_today
